claims: Herein, we identified two potent inhibitors of DHODH, S312 and S416, with favorable drug-like and pharmacokinetic profiles, which all showed broad-spectrum antiviral effects against various RNA viruses, including influenza A virus (H1N1, H3N2, H9N2), Zika virus, Ebola virus, and particularly against the recent novel coronavirus SARS-CoV-2

We also proposed the drug combination of DAA and HTA was a promising strategy for anti-virus treatment and proved that S312 showed more advantageous than Oseltamivir to treat advanced influenza diseases in severely infected animals
We identified that targeting DHODH offers broad-spectrum antiviral efficacies against various RNA viruses, including the DAA-resistant influenza virus and the newly emerged coronavirus SARS-CoV-2

To test whether our potent DHODHi could refresh the important role of targeting DHODH in viral disease, we next explored in vivo efficacy of S312 by intranasally infecting BALB/c mice at a lethal dose of WSN (2LD50=4000pfu) or 2009 pandemic H1N1 (A/Sichuan/01/2009, SC09) (300pfu) virus

We found that the NAH275Y virus did not respond to Osel (20mg/kg/day)-treatment at all but 2.5mg/kg/day of S312 can rescue 50% of mice from lethal infection of NAH275Y virus (Supplementary data Fig. 2C)
We found that direct-targeting DHODHi are broad-spectrum antiviral both in cell culture and in vivo
findings: The data in Fig. 3B showed that the bodyweights of mice from the DMSO-treated ‘virus group’ all dropped to less than 75% and died at D8 p.i
key_statements: Several independent studies searching for host-targeting antiviral collectively end up to compounds targeting the host's pyrimidine synthesis pathway to inhibit virus infections, which indicates that the replication of viruses is widely dependent on the host pyrimidine synthesis[11-25]

More potent pyrimidine synthesis inhibitors, especially ones with the specific drug target, are urgent to be developed to prove whether such an host-targeting antiviral drug is valuable towards clinical use or has any advantages over direct-acting antiviral drugs in antiviral treatment

We identified that targeting DHODH offers broad-spectrum antiviral efficacies against various RNA viruses, including the direct-acting antiviral-resistant influenza virus and the newly emerged coronavirus SARS-CoV-2

Our potent DHODH inhibitors can protect 100% mice from lethal influenza challenge, which is as good as the direct-acting antiviral drugs, and is even effective in the late phase of infection when direct-acting antiviral drug is no longer responding

Drug efficacies were evaluated by quantification of cell viability in both infected and non-infected cells, and the halfmaximal effective concentration (EC50) and the half-cytotoxic concentration (CC50) of the indicated drug were obtained
As shown in Fig. 1D, the antiviral effect of Leflunomide is hardly detectable at the cell culture level (EC50>25 μ M)
The virus plaque in equivalent S312-treatment was not observable at all indicating that S312 is more efficient in inhibiting virus replication than Osel
As all actuate infectious viruses rely on cellular pyrimidine synthesis process to replicate, it is reasonable to speculate that DHODH inhibitors have broad-spectrum antiviral efficacies
A significantly high selectivity index=4746.11 was achieved by S416
The selective index of S416 reached the top of selectivity index=1087.62

When we prepared the manuscript, a severe outbreak of SARS-CoV-2 occurred in Wuhan in December 2019, we responded quickly to examine the antiviral activity of DHODH inhibitors against this new coronavirus

To determine more carefully the efficacy of Teriflunomide, which can be transferred to clinical treatment of SARS-CoV-2 immediately as an approved drug, a bit low MOI of 0.03 (Fig. 2C upper left) were applied

Compared with our previous publication of Remdesivir (EC50=0.77μM, selectivity index>129.87) and Chloroquine (EC50=1.13μM, selectivity index>88.5)[29], which are currently used in clinical trials against SARS-CoV-2, S416 had much greater EC50 and selectivity index values (66.5fold stronger than Chloroquine in EC50) against SARS-CoV-2
In all the previous studies, inhibitors to DHODH or pyrimidine synthesis pathway were only active in vivo at low efficacy showing no obvious superior to direct-acting antiviral drugs

The data in Fig. 3B showed that the bodyweights of mice from the DMSO-treated ‘virus group’ all dropped to less than 75% and died at D8 p.i
The results suggest that S312 of a modest dose (5mg/kg) would achieve the equivalent 100% protection to direct-acting antiviral drug when used from the beginning of infection

We found that the NAH275Y virus did not respond to Osel (20mg/kg/day)-treatment at all but 2.5mg/kg/day of S312 can rescue 50% of mice from lethal infection of NAH275Y virus (Supplementary data Fig. 2C)

When mice were infected with a natural-isolated pandemic strain SC09, which is less sensitive to either Osel (40% protection) or S312 (20% protection) (Fig. 3C), we further observed 100% protection in combined treatment of S312+Osel, indicating that host-targeting antiviral and direct-acting antiviral drug combination can augment therapeutic effects
The cell proliferation rate was barely affected in DHODH-/- cells indicating DHODH is not indispensable for cell growth at least for three days (72 hours)

The results in all provide striking information that DHODH inhibitors are effective in infected animals not only by inhibiting virus replication (Shown in Fig. 3 and Fig. 4) but by eliminating excessive cytokine/chemokine storm
We found that direct-targeting DHODH inhibitors are broad-spectrum antiviral both in cell culture and in vivo

S312 showed active effects in vivo in lethal dose infection of influenza A viruses not only when used from the beginning of infection but in the late phase when direct-acting antiviral drug is not responding anymore
Our data once again proved that DHODH inhibitors could further reduce cytokine storm than direct-acting antiviral drugs when using influenza-A-virus infected animal as a model
